awd_abstract_narration: This award is made as part of the FY 2013 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Joshua Zahl is "Kakeya and Incidence Theorems, Erdos Distance Problem, and Efficient Partitions of Euclidean Space." The host institution for the fellowship is the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Lawrence Guth.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The sponsored research project proved new mathematical theorems in the fields on harmonic analysis and combinatorial geometry. Specifically, the sponsored research developed techniques to understand the behavior of Kakeya sets in three and four dimensions. This research served as the first step of a broader program to analyze the algebraic structure of (hypothetical) counter-examples to the Kakeya conjecture. While the Kakeya Conjecture might appear to be an esoteric question deep within pure mathematics and far from any practical application, the conjecture succinctly captures a central and poorly understood phenomenon in Fourier analysis. Fourier analysis is a major branch of mathematics that underpins the signal processing that enables our modern digital life, and it plays a foundational role in the mathematical description of quantum physics. 
The sponsored research also proved new theorems in combinatorial and incidence geometry. This is a discipline of mathematics that studies the extremal behavior of large collections of simple geometric objects such as points, lines, and spheres. The techniques and ideas used to analyze these problems have found applications in geometric algorithms for problems such as range searching and the construction of spanning trees. The sponsored research in this area has generated interest and sparked follow-up work from researchers in diverse communities throughout mathematics and parts of theoretical computer science.
